item.title: Simon Willison (@simonw)
item.description:
@vadimcomanescu Bicycles and pelicans are both surprisingly hard to draw, and pelicans can't ride bicycles so (at least when I started) there shouldn't be any relevant training data

Also it's funny and I like pelicans

@vadimcomanescu Bicycles and pelicans are both surprisingly hard to draw, and pelicans can't ride bicycles so (at least when I started) there shouldn't be any relevant training data

item.title: Nirant (@NirantK)
item.description:
@_chenglou but a silicon won't have to do a lot of the passive compute and monitoring that our brain does all the time to keep the body humming along

@_chenglou but a silicon won't have to do a lot of the passive compute and monitoring that our brain does all the time to keep the body humming along

— Nirant (@NirantK) February 18, 2026

Replying to:

Cheng Lou @_chenglou

Average adult human brain is 1,300,000 mm¬≥. If there are 150M synapses/mm¬≥, we've got ~195,000,000,000,000 (195 trillion) synapses. If each synapses maps to a neural net weight* then that's a 200T model, at which point it'll start sounding truly human! https://t.co/tK7o9eC38q

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
@EverydayAI_ But Codex and Claude Code are both in the same category - coding tools that can be used for other things (I discuss that category extensively).

They are quite different from Cowork - which is in many ways less capable, but built for other types of knowledge work and more secure

@EverydayAI_ But Codex and Claude Code are both in the same category - coding tools that can be used for other things (I discuss that category extensively).

They are quite different from Cowork - which is in many ways less capable, but built for other types of knowledge work and more secure

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 18, 2026

Jordan Talks Everyday AI @EverydayAI_

@emollick there were a few more, but that's just the bigger stuff that jumped out. i'm a weirdy for details. lol.

the biggest one is codex. i've run cowork almost daily since it came out. (mostly non technical tasks) Since codex app and gpt-5.3 codex extra high, i've done dozens of side

item.title: Simon Willison (@simonw)
item.description:
@jarredsumner Whoa, nice!

Any chance it could grow an option to inline images too, via data: URIs and base64?

(I wonder if that could even work for <video> tags...)

@jarredsumner Whoa, nice!

Any chance it could grow an option to inline images too, via data: URIs and base64?

(I wonder if that could even work for <video> tags...)

— Simon Willison (@simonw) February 18, 2026

Replying to:

Jarred Sumner @jarredsumner

In the next version of Bun

```
bun build --compile --target=browser ./index.html
```

Bundles & inlines all CSS and JS into a single standalone .html file - no external `<script>` or `<link>` tags. One file, zero dependencies. https://t.co/381eXtATKd

item.title: Paras Chopra (@paraschopra)
item.description:
@AryamanIyer3 Some things I learned:

- Prompting CC to test what it builds using headless chromium is essential
- There are subtle bugs in explanations (like in one animation human lifespan is 40 years)
- Asking CC to verify its plan via codex works really well

@AryamanIyer3 Some things I learned:

- Prompting CC to test what it builds using headless chromium is essential
- There are subtle bugs in explanations (like in one animation human lifespan is 40 years)
- Asking CC to verify its plan via codex works really well

— Paras Chopra (@paraschopra) February 18, 2026

Replying to:

Aryaman Iyer @AryamanIyer3

@paraschopra the 'almost' one shot is where all the interesting stuff lives. what broke?

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
Again, I am sure OpenAI will release more enterprise stuff soon, and Google seems to be moving forward a bit with integration into Google workspaces, but the gap right now is surprisingly large as everyone else seems to aim just at the coding market.

Again, I am sure OpenAI will release more enterprise stuff soon, and Google seems to be moving forward a bit with integration into Google workspaces, but the gap right now is surprisingly large as everyone else seems to aim just at the coding market.

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 18, 2026

Replying to:

Ethan Mollick @emollick

Another thing I noticed writing my latest AI guide was how Anthropic seems to be alone in knowledge work apps. Not just Cowork, but Claude for PowerPoint & Excel, as well as job-sppecific skills, plugins & finance/healthcare data integrations

Surprised at the lack of challengers

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
I think they are figuring it out, but there are standouts that no one else seems to have an equivalent to: Google AI Studio is the best API testing tool of the AI Labs, NotebookLM is the only app in its category (& very good), AI Mode for Google search, etc. But all scattered.

I think they are figuring it out, but there are standouts that no one else seems to have an equivalent to: Google AI Studio is the best API testing tool of the AI Labs, NotebookLM is the only app in its category (& very good), AI Mode for Google search, etc. But all scattered.

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 18, 2026

Replying to:

Ethan Mollick @emollick

Writing my latest guide on what AI to use made it really clear how confusing the Google AI situation is.

Great models with radically different harnesses in different apps. Great AI products, mixed in with some bad ones. None of which seem to clearly connect or interact together.

item.title: Alex Volkov (Thursd/AI) (@altryne)
item.description:
I'm at a Claude Code Denver meetup (that's happening in Boulder smh @JacobColling)

One dude created a bunch of .md files with different drug descriptions to get more out of his Claude Code, he particularly suggests LSD for creativity and Adderol for planning. üòÑ

Someone else created a whole orchestration layer with recursive loops.

I did an unofficial survey (p-size 5 people), most don't have agents running for them while they are here talking to me... but some do!

A few folks here seem to be just on the cusp of leaning into the AI psycosis, context switching is definitely the biggest hurdle for folks running multiple agents at once

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
Every few months, I write an updated, idiosyncratic guide on which AIs to use right now.

My new version has the most changes ever, since AI is no longer just about chatbots. To use AI you need to understand how to think about models, apps, and harnesses. https://t.co/m6iTbqsdbK

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
It really isn‚Äôt that hard to see the jagged frontier of AI. Just think about the parts of your job that are vital but that you would be insane to expect an AI to do, even if agents get 10x better. Thats the frontier

The more you use AI the more accurate those assessments will be

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 17, 2026

softRuntime @softRuntime

@swyx @NanoBanana I had Claude build some thumbnail analysis tools, scraped ~3k thumbnails and sliced and diced them a few ways (CLIP feature extraction/colour+saturation/etc).

Trained models to predict views/channel_subs, and used LS as a test set.

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
GDPval remains one of the best benchmarks for doing complex real world agentic tasks.

But worth noting that GDPval-AA is not the same thing. It only uses the public problem set, and all evaluation is done by Gemini, not by humans/specialized graders like in the real GDPval. https://t.co/Gy5JFgveeS

GDPval remains one of the best benchmarks for doing complex real world agentic tasks.

But worth noting that GDPval-AA is not the same thing. It only uses the public problem set, and all evaluation is done by Gemini, not by humans/specialized graders like in the real GDPval. https://t.co/Gy5JFgveeS

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 17, 2026

Quoting:

Lisan al Gaib @scaling01

Sonnet 4.6 the best model on GDPval https://t.co/TxDRbiwMC6

Sonnet 4.6 is now live in Claude Code. It's cheaper than Opus 4.6 and nears Opus-level intelligence, and devs in early testing often preferred it to Opus 4.5. Now the default for Pro and Team plans. https://t.co/ZQErYmBgtE

Sonnet 4.6 is now live in Claude Code. It's cheaper than Opus 4.6 and nears Opus-level intelligence, and devs in early testing often preferred it to Opus 4.5. Now the default for Pro and Team plans. https://t.co/ZQErYmBgtE

— Boris Cherny (@bcherny) February 17, 2026

Quoting:

Claude @claudeai

This is Claude Sonnet 4.6: our most capable Sonnet model yet.

It‚Äôs a full upgrade across coding, computer use, long-context reasoning, agent planning, knowledge work, and design.

It also features a 1M token context window in beta. https://t.co/TDId3XUSRs

item.title: swyx (@swyx)
item.description:
/dev/agents is out of stealth as @dreamer and is the most ambitious full stack consumer+coding agent startup I've ever seen.

when @dps first demoed this to me my jaw dropped. here's the AI Engineer POV:

- Sidekick is an agent that builds agents and publishes on its own app store (having @hbarra cofound is p nice for that)
- unlike most appbuilders, Dreamer agents are full apps/agents - with their own MCPs, triggers, portable memory, settings, notifs, database, serverless functions, logging, prompt management, version control, terminal, etc, with a mix of official and curated LLM APIs for each task eg transcribing vs TTS
- people have been talking about the future of software and the death of the IDE. i think Dreamer is the right form factor for mass adopted personal software agents - you stop fussing over the code, you just use the app and then talk to your Sidekick to fix bugs!!
- very unexpected things happen when you let normies build their own AI apps rather than force them through expensive developers. basketball apps, knockoff harry potter galleries, storytime for kids, caltrain apps.

sadly not an investor, just a friend of the company. but so excited to see this launch!! this is the platform for apps as a "home-cooked meal".

— swyx (@swyx) February 17, 2026

Quoting:

Dreamer @dreamer

Introducing Dreamer.

A place to discover, build, and enjoy agentic apps.
It‚Äôs your home for personal intelligence.

Now in beta. Sign upüëá https://t.co/2cBjClq5eK

@swyx @JeffDean Current paradigm is to minimize wall-clock time, a proxy for that is to **maximize power**. @tri_dao iterates on his kernels until they are power-limited. For wall-clock time optimization, I like to keep this diagram handy https://t.co/XRLIXjNady

item.title: Chris Albon (@chrisalbon)
item.description:
future feel so clear to me:

1. Hollywood establishes hardline anti-ai rules, freezing moviemaking in amber.
2. This provides an opportunity for a new generation of movie makers who embrace ai
3. Customers don‚Äôt care, they watch what they like
4. Hollywood loses its monopoly https://t.co/zq0fJQJgcu

item.description:
You can then use the Figma MCP to go right back into Claude Code with your updated designs.

To get started install the Figma plugin with the following command:

/plugin install figma@claude-plugin-directory

You can then use the Figma MCP to go right back into Claude Code with your updated designs.

item.title: swyx (@swyx)
item.description:
to me its not even about boiling the ocean, its interesting that his old Numbers were about data transfer latencies given physical constraints, but now transfer is kind of much simpler (everything colocated, fewer layers/nodes) then the better consolidated limiting factor for doing back of envelope math is energy!

to me its not even about boiling the ocean, its interesting that his old Numbers were about data transfer latencies given physical constraints, but now transfer is kind of much simpler (everything colocated, fewer layers/nodes) then the better consolidated limiting factor for doing back of envelope math is energy!

— swyx (@swyx) February 17, 2026

Replying to:

Yaroslav Bulatov @yaroslavvb

@JeffDean talked about pico-joules with @swyx . Capabilities frontier is hot right now, but soon¬†we'll want to bring these to 10 billion people without boiling the ocean. FLOPs energy consumption is tiny relative to data movement. Slide from Bill Daly - https://t.co/r91CQioWhc

item.title: Zhihu Frontier (@ZhihuFrontier)
item.description:
ü§ñ @UnitreeRobotics robots performed martial arts at China's Spring Festival Gala ‚Äî sparking major debate on Zhihu.
From a technical lens, Zhihu contributor ‰πüËØ¥ analyzed what actually matters üëá

1Ô∏è‚É£ Sync with autonomy
In the opening backflip, robots jumped together ‚Äî but landed at slightly different times due to balance variance.
Yet they re-aligned perfectly in the next move. That means each robot was:
‚Ä¢ Executing choreography
‚Ä¢ Running real-time posture computation
‚Ä¢ Re-syncing with the group tempo
That's distributed coordination, not canned playback.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Slippery glass stage
The stage was glass (very slick).
Robots still completed flips & martial arts moves smoothly.
Each wore anti-slip "shoes" ‚Äî modular, human-like adaptation to terrain üëü

3Ô∏è‚É£ Real biomechanics
The sweeping-leg move wasn't a visual trick.
Frame-by-frame: toe + supporting hand dual-point balance ‚Äî same force principle as humans.
They didn't fake it via joint rotation. They followed physics üëã

4Ô∏è‚É£ Shared human tools
Staff, nunchaku, sword ‚Äî all gripped with high-DOF fingers.
Not props "attached" to hands.
This matters: it means robots can use standardized human tools in real work scenarios ‚Üí lower logistics frictionüîß

5Ô∏è‚É£ Safety awareness
In one scene, a child runs in.
Before a "splitting strike," the robot subtly measures distance using the staff tip.
üëâWhy? The child won't land at a pre-calibrated spot.
That's real-time spacing calibration ‚Äî same trick used in human stage combat.

6Ô∏è‚É£ On-the-fly rescue
During a vault, a child loses balance mid-air.
Front-row robot lowers its staff faster to avoid contact.
Back row stays steady.
That's observation ‚Üí anomaly detection ‚Üí instant adjustment, which means robots using multiple contingency plans, not single-script execution.

7Ô∏è‚É£ "Non-human" joint advantage
Some moves included reverse wrist support impossible for humans.
In the pommel-horse segment, robots leveraged extra mechanical joint degrees of freedom to perform support angles humans physically cannot.
The final reverse-accelerated jump sequence was especially striking ‚Äî if coordination involved shared visual data between robots, that's team sync beyond human capability. Even if camera-assisted, it exceeds biological limits.

üìå This performance signals something real:
‚Ä¢ High-precision real-time control
‚Ä¢ Multi-agent synchronization
‚Ä¢ Terrain adaptation
‚Ä¢ Human-robot safety co-modeling
On pure physical dexterity & coordination, humanoids may already surpass most humans.
Our advantage right now? Cost üí∞

üìùFull analysis:
https://t.co/GNyYCzG8nn
#Unitree #HumanoidRobots #EmbodiedAI #Robotics #AI

item.description:

@JaredSleeper "Emma" what's this?

— Nirant (@NirantK) February 17, 2026

Replying to:

Jared Sleeper @JaredSleeper

Investing today is about navigating uncertainty in how value accrues in the intelligence stack.

The challenge for software is that it is "just" context today.

But there are many scenarios in which context is even more valuable as intelligence explodes.

Exciting times! https://t.co/Ox3go1BL0p

item.title: Nirant (@NirantK)
item.description:
Almost everything you need in a large codebase or any long running agent is verification

Everything is downstream of that. How do you know when to use verification? That's a harness!

Verification is the checker, harness is the process owner and sometimes the process runner https://t.co/VOzH8acSBY

Almost everything you need in a large codebase or any long running agent is verification

Everything is downstream of that. How do you know when to use verification? That's a harness!

Verification is the checker, harness is the process owner and sometimes the process runner https://t.co/VOzH8acSBY

— Nirant (@NirantK) February 17, 2026

Quoting:

himanshu @himanshustwts

one of amazing booths at AI Summit which excited me today was @sachdh - he is building AthenaAgent for the world. Athena is repo-aligned coding agents for complex ENTERPRISES where general harnesses fail.

they do repo-specific post training + continuous verification harness. https://t.co/XrJKdYSjgj

item.title: Nirant (@NirantK)
item.description:
Reasonable to assume that I'm somewhat AI "native":

I've written a NLP book for devs, trained a Hindi LM in 2019. I can promise you that humans mogg AI right now on quality/finish/polish.

Sadly, it is very difficult to tell quality for anything outside my narrow expertise https://t.co/bhZookB7A7

Reasonable to assume that I'm somewhat AI "native":

I've written a NLP book for devs, trained a Hindi LM in 2019. I can promise you that humans mogg AI right now on quality/finish/polish.

Sadly, it is very difficult to tell quality for anything outside my narrow expertise https://t.co/bhZookB7A7

— Nirant (@NirantK) February 17, 2026

Quoting:

Kriti Gupta @kriti_kg

Asked a founder what it means to be an AI-native company -

‚ÄòWhen I have a problem, I used to find a human solution and then use AI to automate.

Now I find the AI solution first and then have human intervention to perfect it.‚Äô

item.title: Nirant (@NirantK)
item.description:
@daniel_mcdowell Why can't I can just let my AI talk to their AI?

@daniel_mcdowell Why can't I can just let my AI talk to their AI?

— Nirant (@NirantK) February 17, 2026

Replying to:

Daniel McDowell @daniel_mcdowell

I tell my students that one of the main reasons not to over-rely on AI for research/writing is b/c--at some point--you're going to have a face-to-face conversation with someone who matters, and if you don't actually know some things, that interaction will not go well for you.

They did shift the overton window tho in some ways around privacy, IP

item.title: Nirant (@NirantK)
item.description:
Prediction: ChatGPT will get pulled in 2 different directions:

Publishers want to target the richest, best fit buyers i.e. üá∫üá∏ and employees in India.

But via Enterprise they go to ad-free plans + Claude
üáÆüá≥ want affordable + entertainment

This is ICP friction is going to slow down ads maturity i.e. targeting within the product

And create room for others to expand e.g. Instagram, WhatsApp, Google AI mode itself

The consumer victory of ChatGPT is not a foregone conclusion *yet*

As for startups building on top of ChatGPT, we do remember what happened to Zynga, right? right??

Prediction: ChatGPT will get pulled in 2 different directions:

Publishers want to target the richest, best fit buyers i.e. üá∫üá∏ and employees in India.

But via Enterprise they go to ad-free plans + Claude
üáÆüá≥ want affordable + entertainment

This is ICP friction is going to slow down ads maturity i.e. targeting within the product

And create room for others to expand e.g. Instagram, WhatsApp, Google AI mode itself

The consumer victory of ChatGPT is not a foregone conclusion *yet*

As for startups building on top of ChatGPT, we do remember what happened to Zynga, right? right??

— Nirant (@NirantK) February 17, 2026

Quoting:

Tejeshwi Sharma üáÆüá≥ @tejeshwi_sharma

ChatGPT is becoming for AI what Google was for the web: default discovery + habit layer.

Once the platform normalizes behavior, startups build vertically on top of it.

India-specific use cases (language, exams, commerce, health, local services) are ripe.

I expect a cambrian

item.title: Chris Albon (@chrisalbon)

This puts it exactly right. Either we are fighting against each other for a relative larger piece of finite pie. Or we are fighting against the universe for a piece of an infinite pie. https://t.co/ZYZvDAYBAn

This puts it exactly right. Either we are fighting against each other for a relative larger piece of finite pie. Or we are fighting against the universe for a piece of an infinite pie. https://t.co/ZYZvDAYBAn

Quoting:

James Cham @jamescham

so much of this depends on whether there‚Äôs a limited amount of work to get done so the AI agents will do all of it; or that there are a limitless number of problems with the world we could be tackling.

Replying to:

Tom @toms_dome

@emollick missing principle: what happens when constitution conflicts with user intent

built agents that follow rules so hard they become useless - 'be helpful' vs 'avoid harm' breaks constantly in edge cases

who wins when principles collide

item.title: Nirant (@NirantK)
item.description:
@sandeepssrin At it's core, LLMs are a horizontal & so is code.

The first and second version of code generation in India (IT Services and SaaS) worked because the Govt did not pick the winners

Since the Govt is now in the business of picking winners, I can expect that it'll do a worse job :)

@sandeepssrin At it's core, LLMs are a horizontal & so is code.

The first and second version of code generation in India (IT Services and SaaS) worked because the Govt did not pick the winners

Since the Govt is now in the business of picking winners, I can expect that it'll do a worse job :)

— Nirant (@NirantK) February 17, 2026

Replying to:

Sandeep Srinivasa @sandeepssrin

Im kind of very very surprised that not one event at India ai summit deals with codegen.

I mean literally Anthropic is disrupting the stock market daily cos of it.
And OpenAI+Github is being threatened.
Not to mention the existential threat to India's economy.

And not one

— Nirant (@NirantK) February 17, 2026

Quoting:

Drew Breunig @dbreunig

Lessons from OpenClaw that I expect OpenAI to adopt shortly:

1. Inter-agent communication doesn't need a protocol, just a place to post.
2. Every agent should integrate with every messaging platform. That's the primary UI.
3. People are willing to pay to have an AI pet.

item.title: Alex Volkov (Thursd/AI) (@altryne)
item.description:
@MatthewBerman @steipete telegram does have true streaming, but it only works within a DM with a clanker, on bots where DM Topics are enabled

https://t.co/6NXDqXrkCd

@MatthewBerman @steipete telegram does have true streaming, but it only works within a DM with a clanker, on bots where DM Topics are enabled

https://t.co/6NXDqXrkCd

— Alex Volkov (Thursd/AI) (@altryne) February 17, 2026

Quoting:

Alex Volkov (Thursd/AI) @altryne

Here's what actually works:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Open https://t.co/zeIzSdKXYM (the mini app!)
2Ô∏è‚É£ Select your bot
3Ô∏è‚É£ Find and enable "Threaded Mode"
4Ô∏è‚É£ Set streamMode: "partial" in your bot config

That's it. DM streaming will work after that if your're using Bot API https://t.co/CBV8ElX8u0

Replying to:

Matthew Berman @MatthewBerman

@steipete I think that's just the way the feature works. It constantly replaces the text until the final output finishes. My clanker said because Telegram doesn't have true streaming, this was a "workaround" but that didn't seem right.

1Ô∏è‚É£ Open https://t.co/zeIzSdKXYM (the mini app!)

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
Some other research showing the same thing. https://t.co/4mkvzLsJ73

Some other research showing the same thing. https://t.co/4mkvzLsJ73

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 17, 2026

Quoting:

Ethan Mollick @emollick

The research on AI companions and mental health is still very preliminary & unclear as to long-term impact. Seems like an important topic to research right now.

(I would also hope that xAI is tracking anonymized data about their new companion product for known potential harms) https://t.co/bvU8X2tWbE

Replying to:

Ethan Mollick @emollick

And it is unclear whether this is net good or net bad for people! We just don‚Äôt have enough research yet. Some evidence suggests that people using AI for emotional support think it helps them, but who, and for how long, is unknown. https://t.co/YEI6TPJqjs https://t.co/EQUsAI1dKU

@techczech @lgrammel @patio11 Yeah, that's a good point about large IT systems that defy understanding - I've worked at tech companies before where I didn't come close to understanding the entirety of the product

But my value there was still connected to how much of it I DID understand - the more the better

@techczech @lgrammel @patio11 Yeah, that's a good point about large IT systems that defy understanding - I've worked at tech companies before where I didn't come close to understanding the entirety of the product

Dominik Lukes @techczech

Muratcan Koylan @koylanai

The problem is how memory gets into the context window and what happens when compaction wipes it.

OpenClaw loads MEMORY[.]md plus the last two days of daily logs at session start. Static injection. Everything gets stuffed into the context window upfront. When the window fills https://t.co/m3icO15JsR https://t.co/htfazmQnEH

Replying to:

swyx @swyx

pretty good and concise posthoc summary of why openclaw worked https://t.co/HDFG2fwzXX

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
I am sure they are optimizing/growth hacking or something, but there just is no way to onboard yourself if you are a newcomer trying to understand these tools. And it is like the companies are suggesting you ignore them, when some are vital (Canvas on Gemini) or Deep Research

I am sure they are optimizing/growth hacking or something, but there just is no way to onboard yourself if you are a newcomer trying to understand these tools. And it is like the companies are suggesting you ignore them, when some are vital (Canvas on Gemini) or Deep Research

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 16, 2026

Replying to:

Ethan Mollick @emollick

If you haven't hit the little plus button on your favorite chatbot recently, it is a complete hodgepodge mess that nobody not on X would understand: Canvas and Web search and Learning and confusing icons.

I am not even calling out any of the Big Three directly, its all of them.

item.title: Simon Willison (@simonw)
item.description:
@k_kohlbrenner @lgrammel My specific problem is the number of projects I have running at once - I'm up to over a dozen things I'm actively shipping new features for (enabled by coding agent boosts), the cognitive load of even remembering what they can do in the first place is high already!

@k_kohlbrenner @lgrammel My specific problem is the number of projects I have running at once - I'm up to over a dozen things I'm actively shipping new features for (enabled by coding agent boosts), the cognitive load of even remembering what they can do in the first place is high already!

— Simon Willison (@simonw) February 16, 2026

Replying to:

kohl @k_kohlbrenner

@simonw @lgrammel I think it‚Äôs more what should I build next and why vs what have I built thus far and why.

What vibecoded product features are you building you can‚Äôt grok?

You can ask questions over your codebase at any time to understand it, no? Deepwiki, deep research, etc isn‚Äôt helping you

item.title: Alex Volkov (Thursd/AI) (@altryne)
item.description:
@iAmHenryMascot @openclaw Oh interesting, why clean if you can parse them out? For easier lookup?

@iAmHenryMascot @openclaw Oh interesting, why clean if you can parse them out? For easier lookup?

— Alex Volkov (Thursd/AI) (@altryne) February 16, 2026

Replying to:

Henry Mascot @iAmHenryMascot

@altryne @openclaw thats neat I should build that.

I currently run a hook that cleans up the session file of tool calls, which is 90% of file size.
And a cron that auto indexes every hour.

Issue is if session just ended that context wouldn't have been cleaned instantly and index
item.content:encoded:

Henry Mascot @iAmHenryMascot

@altryne @openclaw thats neat I should build that.

I currently run a hook that cleans up the session file of tool calls, which is 90% of file size.
And a cron that auto indexes every hour.

Issue is if session just ended that context wouldn't have been cleaned instantly and index

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
Underestimated moment of agency/leverage is that many systems are being redesigned for AI & fluid for the first time in a long time (how do you hire? How does scientific publishing work?)

That creates an opening for small groups to set patterns that could define future systems

item.title: Daniel Vassallo (@dvassallo)
item.description:
@levelsio @nikitabier @photomatt Clubhouse had a similar idea when. Every account had to be vouched by someone else. So I might see levelsio in my replies and on hover I can see who brought him to the platform.

But maybe making it based on follows and follows of followers is more scaleable.

@levelsio @nikitabier @photomatt Clubhouse had a similar idea when. Every account had to be vouched by someone else. So I might see levelsio in my replies and on hover I can see who brought him to the platform.

But maybe making it based on follows and follows of followers is more scaleable.

— Daniel Vassallo (@dvassallo) February 16, 2026

Replying to:

@levelsio @levelsio

This would be genius actually @nikitabier

Where people I follow can reply to my tweets but also the people they follow (like 2nd degree follows)

And maybe you can see that in small text too like:

@photomatt (via @levelsio):
"Bla bla bla"

Then if you realize that's an AI bot https://t.co/pNYTcpLZUD

item.title: Simon Willison (@simonw)
item.description:
@lgrammel I don't think that's going to work here - cognitive debt isn't about not understanding the code, it's about not understanding the features of the product deeply enough to confidently decide what to build next

@lgrammel I don't think that's going to work here - cognitive debt isn't about not understanding the code, it's about not understanding the features of the product deeply enough to confidently decide what to build next

— Simon Willison (@simonw) February 16, 2026

Replying to:

Lars Grammel @lgrammel

In domains where shipping speed is key, we will give up the notion of "understanding the codebase" and treat it like assembly. Todays models may not be good enough, but this is where I see things going. https://t.co/5VjboVfBEI

item.title: Paras Chopra (@paraschopra)
item.description:
Ever wondered why OpenClaw went viral but many other similar projects didn‚Äôt?

Well, just look at the number of projects by OpenClaw‚Äôs creator.

Virality is a function of number of attempts. It‚Äôs so rare and unpredictable that your best bet is to maximize taking shots at it.

Same is true with tweets/videos. You‚Äôd see that the fastest growing accounts are those that produce a ton, and not those that keep perfecting a single thing that they hope to go viral.

Ever wondered why OpenClaw went viral but many other similar projects didn‚Äôt?

Well, just look at the number of projects by OpenClaw‚Äôs creator.

Same is true with tweets/videos. You‚Äôd see that the fastest growing accounts are those that produce a ton, and not those that keep perfecting a single thing that they hope to go viral.

— Paras Chopra (@paraschopra) February 16, 2026

item.title: Zhihu Frontier (@ZhihuFrontier)
item.description:
üéá @Alibaba_Qwen Drops Qwen 3.5 on Chinese New Year's Eve, opening the Spring Festival AI race ‚Äî What's Worth Watching?
üí°Here's a concise breakdown of key viewpoints from AI community:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Zhihu contributor ÂàòËÅ™NLP:
Observed strengths:
‚úî Better webpage replication & stronger fine-grained image recognition
‚úî Improved object detection & spatial ordering vs Qwen3-VL
‚úî OCR & tables remain strong
Limitations:
‚Ä¢ Complex spatial reasoning still weak
‚Ä¢ Clock reading still problematic
‚Ä¢ Reasoning improved but not fully stable
Some scenarios approach Gemini 3.0 Pro level ‚Äî but inconsistently, and generalization needs work.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Zhihu contributor ÊÆµÂ∞èËçâ:
Focus: architecture + open-source positioning.
‚Ä¢ Largest open-sourced Qwen so far: 397B-A17B MoE
‚Ä¢ <5% expert activation ‚Üí extreme sparsity, keeping knowledge capacity while reducing inference cost
‚Ä¢ Also notable: ¬•0.8 / million tokens for a flagship model ‚Äî highly aggressive pricing, fitting the Agent era's rising token consumption

3Ô∏è‚É£ Zhihu contributor Âπ≥Âá°:
NeurIPS Best Paper-level work is translating fast.
‚Ä¢ Gated Attention wasn't benchmark-only research ‚Äî it required heavy experimentation + open-source rigor.
‚Ä¢ Many expected production models around 2026.
‚Ä¢ However, Qwen3.5-Plus delivered in ~6 months.
üîÆThis is a rare case of theory ‚Üí large-scale engineering ‚Üí productization happening unusually fast.

4Ô∏è‚É£ Zhihu contributor van dark:
Hands-on impression:
‚Ä¢ Performance felt below expectations, with no clear gap vs Qwen3-Max
‚Ä¢ Front-end & mini-game generation below Kimi K2.5 / GLM5 and closer to MiniMax M2.5 level
Advantage:
‚úî Fast inference
‚úî Potentially good for Agent workflows

üí¨ Join the Discussion:
https://t.co/pNpySsK0eQ
#Qwen35 #Alibaba #Qwen #MoE #Multimodal #AI #LLM #Agent #Tech

2Ô∏è‚É£ Zhihu contributor ÊÆµÂ∞èËçâ:
Focus: architecture + open-source positioning.
‚Ä¢ Largest open-sourced Qwen so far: 397B-A17B MoE
‚Ä¢ <5% expert activation ‚Üí extreme sparsity, keeping knowledge capacity while reducing inference cost
‚Ä¢ Also notable: ¬•0.8 / million tokens for a flagship model ‚Äî highly aggressive pricing, fitting the Agent era's rising token consumption

3Ô∏è‚É£ Zhihu contributor Âπ≥Âá°:
NeurIPS Best Paper-level work is translating fast.
‚Ä¢ Gated Attention wasn't benchmark-only research ‚Äî it required heavy experimentation + open-source rigor.
‚Ä¢ Many expected production models around 2026.
‚Ä¢ However, Qwen3.5-Plus delivered in ~6 months.
üîÆThis is a rare case of theory ‚Üí large-scale engineering ‚Üí productization happening unusually fast.

4Ô∏è‚É£ Zhihu contributor van dark:
Hands-on impression:
‚Ä¢ Performance felt below expectations, with no clear gap vs Qwen3-Max
‚Ä¢ Front-end & mini-game generation below Kimi K2.5 / GLM5 and closer to MiniMax M2.5 level
Advantage:
‚úî Fast inference
‚úî Potentially good for Agent workflows

üí¨ Join the Discussion:
https://t.co/pNpySsK0eQ
#Qwen35 #Alibaba #Qwen #MoE #Multimodal #AI #LLM #Agent #Tech

— Zhihu Frontier (@ZhihuFrontier) February 16, 2026

item.title: Paras Chopra (@paraschopra)
item.description:
I think it‚Äôs safe to assume that the value of human cognitive labor will likely rapidly decline to zero.

In such a world, what skills should you hone?

My bet is that any skill that requires showing up in person and taking responsibility will still be in demand.

Think sales, politics, leadership, care giving, coaching, teaching, surgery.

Humans are highly attuned to attending to other people in a physical setting, and even the best humanoids won‚Äôt be able match that in near future.

I think it‚Äôs safe to assume that the value of human cognitive labor will likely rapidly decline to zero.

In such a world, what skills should you hone?

My bet is that any skill that requires showing up in person and taking responsibility will still be in demand.

Think sales, politics, leadership, care giving, coaching, teaching, surgery.

Humans are highly attuned to attending to other people in a physical setting, and even the best humanoids won‚Äôt be able match that in near future.

— Paras Chopra (@paraschopra) February 16, 2026

1. Inter-agent communication doesn't need a protocol, just a pl‚Ä¶

RT @dbreunig: Lessons from OpenClaw that I expect OpenAI to adopt shortly:

1. Inter-agent communication doesn't need a protocol, just a pl‚Ä¶

— Nirant (@NirantK) February 16, 2026

Retweeted:

Drew Breunig @dbreunig

Lessons from OpenClaw that I expect OpenAI to adopt shortly:

1. Inter-agent communication doesn't need a protocol, just a place to post.
2. Every agent should integrate with every messaging platform. That's the primary UI.
3. People are willing to pay to have an AI pet.
